STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 21, 2024
Ursula Regina Ahart
Transitional Living Program
548 E Grand Blv.
DETROIT, MI, 48207-3534
RE: License#: CB820201475
Dear Ms. Ahart:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 8/8/2024 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
In one of five new employee records reviewed, where the applicant had resided in
Florida within the last 5 years prior to the 12/6/2023 date of hire, the record did
not show documentation of a Florida child abuse clearance.
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law.
(1) An agency shall comply with the child protection
law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
One of five new employee records reviewed, where the employee’s date of hire
was 11/6/2023, did not show documentation of a DCWL (Division of Child Welfare
Licensing) children protective services history review, at the time of the onsite file
review. The agency obtained a clearance from DCWL on the employee on
8/13/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with the
youth's biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.
In three of four open youth records reviewed where a 30-day report was
completed, the report did not show documentation of the reason why the case
responsibility changed or whether there were any modifications to the existing
service plans.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2022, CAP approved 9/7/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
Two of three closed youth records reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2022, CAP approved 9/7/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.

(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Two of three closed youth records reviewed did not show documentation of (d) as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2022, CAP approved 9/7/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.
One of four open youth records reviewed showed the youth was due a dental
examination by 2/25/2024 and one was not documented.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of four open youth records reviewed did not show documentation of a
January, April or July 2024 quarterly contract between the youth and agency.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2022, CAP approved 9/7/2022.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.

Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward
Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
One four open youth records reviewed did not show documentation of an FTM for
the youth’s 11/3/2023- 1/17/2024 and 4/16/2024-7/12/2024 updated service plan.
Repeat Violation
Interim 2023, CAP approved 9/26/2023.
Renewal 2022, CAP approved 9/7/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
Nothing this inspection.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12509(3)(o) Independent living record:
• The agency was advised developing a 30-day report form, which highlights
information as required by R400.12418(3) may aid it in consistently documenting
compliance to the rule.
R400.12212(2)(h) & R400.12214 Personnel record & Compliance with the child
protection late:
• The agency was advised adding a category asking if the applicant has lived out
of state within the last five years; and completion of the CWL form 4624 to its
new employment hire checklist may aid it in reminding the agency to complete
both required clearances before hire, and aid it in achieving compliance to these
rules.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one corrective action plan during the reporting period. The
corrective action plan related to the agency Interim inspection. During that
inspection 5 rule violations were established, 1 of which was a repeat violations
from 2023. The number of individual cases cited for the repeat citaton was the
same, which was 1.
With regard to that corrective action plan the systems the agency reported were in
place: employment checklist, secondary approval of hiring packages by the
director, amendment of an existing spreadsheet to add a 30-day due date related
to FTMs, supervisory review of FTM during monthly supervisor/worker meeting
were. Proof of these implementations were seen per the file reviews or via
example shown to me. The agency made some process on the corrective action
plan but was not completely successful with all as indicated by the repeat
violations in this report.
The agency is advised to continue its focus and efforts to refine and further
executive the corrective action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 8/1/2024. The chief
administrator’s report spoke to the past years rule violations and the plans the
agency initiated related to them. Additionally, their efforts to ensure timely
uploading of required documents to show compliances.
During the entrance conference the agency also reported areas of success,
growth, and expansion plans. The agency reported a 100% youth graduation
success rate for a second year. It has retained staff, it was able to hired another
independent living case worker, and a full-time life skills coach. Additionally, the
agency is seeking to either open a mother and baby program or to extend its
current program to offer such services further.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2024-2025 budget and a March 31, 2023, independent
financial audit report. A review of these documents did not show an area of
concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to my discussion with the program manager and the chief
administrator, I interviewed the agency’s independent living (IL) life skills coach,
an independent living youth advocate, and an IL case manager. The staff

interviewed reported positive accolades about the agency’s services to youths and
to feeling supported by the agency. Areas of need or growth included the agency
being able to have an onsite therapist for the youths and to provide work cell
phones for workers.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not reveal any concerns. The agency has
sufficient space and files are stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Not applicable.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
August 13, 2024
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
